unnormalised: **Rental Agreements: Don't Be a Bakra Before You Sign!**
normalised: **Rental Agreements: Don't Be a Bakra Before You Sign!**

unnormalised: Hey everyone, Rohan here! Let's talk rental agreements. Because honestly, signing one without reading it properly is like ordering biryani from a roadside dhaba at 3 AM – you're probably gonna regret it.
normalised: Hey everyone, Rohan here! Let's talk rental agreements. Because honestly, signing one without reading it properly is like ordering biryani from a roadside dhaba at three A.M. – you're probably gonna regret it.

unnormalised: Seriously though, in Mumbai, Delhi, Bangalore… wherever you are in India, understanding your rental agreement (also known as a "leave and license agreement" sometimes, especially in Maharashtra) is super important. It’s not just some formality your chacha told you to ignore.
normalised: Seriously though, in Mumbai, Delhi, Bangalore… wherever you are in India, understanding your rental agreement (also known as a "leave and license agreement" sometimes, especially in Maharashtra) is super important. It’s not just some formality your chacha told you to ignore.

unnormalised: First off, READ THE WHOLE THING. Don’t just glance at the rent amount (which, let's be real, is probably outrageous anyway). Check the clauses about security deposit – how much? When do you get it back? What deductions are allowed? Make sure it aligns with what you discussed with Uncle Sharma, the landlord. Get everything in writing. Verbal promises are worth less than a Rs. 5 coin these days.
normalised: First off, READ THE WHOLE THING. Don’t just glance at the rent amount (which, let's be real, is probably outrageous anyway). Check the clauses about security deposit – how much? When do you get it back? What deductions are allowed? Make sure it aligns with what you discussed with Uncle Sharma, the landlord. Get everything in writing. Verbal promises are worth less than a rupee five coin these days.

unnormalised: Pay close attention to the lock-in period. If you leave before that, you might lose your deposit. Negotiate it if possible! Also, what about maintenance charges? Who pays for them? Are you responsible for painting the flat after 11 months, before moving out on 01/01/2025? All this needs to be crystal clear.
normalised: Pay close attention to the lock-in period. If you leave before that, you might lose your deposit. Negotiate it if possible! Also, what about maintenance charges? Who pays for them? Are you responsible for painting the flat after eleven months, before moving out on first January two thousand and twenty five? All this needs to be crystal clear.

unnormalised: And speaking of clarity, check the notice period. Usually it's 1-2 months. If you're planning a surprise trip to Goa on 15/08/2024, you don't want to be stuck paying rent for an empty apartment.
normalised: And speaking of clarity, check the notice period. Usually it's one to two months. If you're planning a surprise trip to Goa on fifteenth August two thousand and twenty four, you don't want to be stuck paying rent for an empty apartment.

unnormalised: Also, is subletting allowed? If you're thinking of renting out that spare room to your cousin visiting from Patna, make sure the agreement allows it. Otherwise, you might find yourself in hot water. Landlords usually have clauses that prohibit commercial activities, for instance, so don't start your tiffin service from the kitchen at 09:00 hrs unless you’ve clarified it.
normalised: Also, is subletting allowed? If you're thinking of renting out that spare room to your cousin visiting from Patna, make sure the agreement allows it. Otherwise, you might find yourself in hot water. Landlords usually have clauses that prohibit commercial activities, for instance, so don't start your tiffin service from the kitchen at nine zero zero hours unless you’ve clarified it.

unnormalised: Finally, get it registered! It’s usually a shared expense between you and the landlord. Registration gives the agreement legal standing, especially helpful if things go south and you need to involve the authorities. Think of it as getting your relationship “official” with the apartment – way less drama in the long run. This registration is often mandatory under state laws for agreements exceeding, say, 11 months.

unnormalised: So, next time you're about to sign a rental agreement, remember Rohan’s advice. Do your homework, read everything carefully, and don't be a bakra! Good luck finding that perfect flat, and may your rent always be negotiable! Remember the Lal Bahadur Shastri Institute of Management entrance exam on 17/02/2024, and be prepared for a verbal agreement on rental conditions!
